title: Ukraine tension fuels commodities crunch
text:
Good evening,

Political tensions over Ukraine have shone a spotlight on global energy supplies, but surging demand and supply shortages are affecting stockpiles of a range of other commodities, from industrial metals to food.

The price of crude oil, which today hit a seven-year high of $96.16, is likely to stay elevated, the International Energy Agency said last week, unless producers make more of an effort to turn on the taps. The increases are showing up in record prices on the forecourt: the average cost of a litre of petrol in the UK hit 148p per litre at the weekend, while diesel reached 151.57p last Thursday.

Gas prices are also being driven up by the situation in Ukraine and lower flows from Russia, with Europe's storage facilities only a third full. Natural gas contracts for next-month delivery jumped 12 per cent today to €83.41 per megawatt hour.

Sanctions against Russia could have a dramatic effect on wider commodities markets that are already depleted by the bounceback in demand and myriad supply chain problems, leaving them highly vulnerable to disruption.

The commodities and raw materials crunch is particularly pronounced in metals markets, with traders paying large premiums for immediate supplies. “This is the most extreme inventory environment,” said one analyst at Goldman Sachs. “It's a completely unprecedented episode. There is no supply response.” 

Major exchanges have less than one week's supply of copper stocks, while supplies of aluminium — the price of which hit a 13-year high last week — are also low, as smelters in Europe and China cut capacity because of surging energy prices. Demand for lithium, dubbed the new “white gold” because of its use in batteries for electric cars, is also racing ahead of supply.

Paper shortages, exacerbated by strikes at mills in Finland, are affecting companies from newspapers to financial groups that need to print millions of shareholder documents. “You've got paper prices spiking and everyone chasing too few tonnes,” said one consultant. “It's an absolute mess.”

Reserves of arabica coffee beans are at their lowest level on the ICE futures exchange in more than 20 years, with the possibility of an “uncontrolled price spike”, according to one analyst.

Rising input costs for consumer companies have been a recurrent theme in the current US earnings season, leading to price rises everywhere from PepsiCo to Unilever, alongside increased labour and shipping costs and other supply chain problems.

The end result, according to one strategist, is that “US businesses have managed to do something never before accomplished, which is to lump four years' worth of price increases into one”.

Latest news

  • UK banking group NatWest said it would close 32 branches as customers opted to move online (Evening Standard)

  • Federal Reserve policymaker James Bullard said he was worried the US central bank was not moving fast enough to contain inflation (CNBC)

  • Outdoor grill maker Weber said it would raise prices for the second time in six months, as it faces rising costs and supply chain constraints

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

The US government is busy rewriting public health guidance to herald the end of the “full-blown” pandemic, although some experts fear that polling data on this year's midterm elections might be driving the changes rather than public health.

Slower growth and higher inflation will characterise the post-Covid world economy, writes contributing editor Ruchir Sharma. The 2021 bounceback only looked good because so many countries had shrunk the year before. The real test will be “how fast economies can grow after the pandemic, once base effects fade and stimulus recedes”, he says.

Latest for the UK/Europe

Spending in smaller UK shopping areas has bounced back more strongly than in London and other big cities that are more reliant on office workers. The Lex column says retailers need to adapt to new city rhythms. Use our tracker to see how the pandemic has hit spending in your area.

UK regulators today clamped down on the buy now, pay later market that rocketed during the pandemic, quadrupling in size in 2020. Critics say the schemes could encourage spending even when users cannot afford it.

Our Big Read runs the rule over Emmanuel Macron's economic record, as he prepares his attempt for re-election as French president. The country appears to have recovered well from the pandemic, with GDP returning to its previous level last autumn ahead of the rest of Europe.

Global latest

China has claimed success in stopping Covid wrecking the Winter Olympics in Beijing, but the outlook is less rosy in Hong Kong, which recorded another record number of infections today. Taiwan, which has been one of the most successful countries in controlling the pandemic, is easing its tight border controls of the past two years.

Economic recovery in the US lifted remittances to Mexico and northern Central American countries more than 25 per cent last year to reach record levels as demand grew for migrant labour.

Need to know: business

Goods traffic is moving again across the Canada-US border after police removed protesters blocking the Ambassador Bridge over mandatory vaccination. Our Big Read looks at the wider motives driving the protesters.

Barry McCarthy, the new head of Peloton, a home fitness company that increased in popularity during the pandemic, told the Financial Times he was not considering a sale and would focus on digital content. The company's market value had at one point collapsed by more than 80 per cent.

Moderna, the US mRNA vaccine pioneer, is in talks with the UK government about investing in research and manufacturing, a move that could offer a significant boost to the country's post-Brexit science strategy.

The World of Work

For those of you finding it difficult enough to navigate new hybrid ways of working without having to find time for endless meetings, there could be hope on the horizon. Some companies are slashing the number of gatherings they hold, or banning them altogether. “Managers need to say, ‘Do I really need this meeting?' And then cancel it,” says Joe Allen, co-author of Suddenly Hybrid: Managing the Modern Meeting.

How do you sell access to gyms when everyone is forced to exercise at home? Gympass boss Cesar Carvalho explains how he expanded his company's digital services to survive in our latest How to Lead interview.

One of the key structural changes in the labour market over the pandemic period has been the exodus of older people from the UK workforce. Since the crisis began, the number of economically inactive 50 to 64-year-olds has risen by a quarter of a million.

The FT Editorial Board considers the pros and cons of the next hot topic in post-pandemic job redesign: the four-day working week.

No matter how many days a week you work, going back to the office means re-engaging with colleagues you may not particularly like. Writer and comedian Viv Groskop offers tips on how to deal with the jerk at work.

And finally . . . 

Ever wondered where that low droning sound with no discernible source is coming from? Is it even real? The FT Magazine investigates the as-yet unexplained international mystery of “the Hum”.
